title: The least common multiple
text: The LCM or least common multiple of a set of numbers is the smallest positive integer that is divisible by all those numbers.
speech: The LCM or least common multiple of a set of numbers is the smallest positive integer that is divisible by all those numbers.
pacedSpeech: The LCM or least common multiple of a set of numbers is the smallest positive integer that is divisible by all those numbers.

title: The least common multiple
text: To combine the fractions, we want to find the LCM of the denominators. What is it?
speech: To combine the fractions, we want to find the LCM of the denominators. What is it?
pacedSpeech: To combine the fractions, we want to find the LCM of the denominators. What is it?

title: Multiplication by $$1$$
text: We must multiple each expression by the appropriate form of $$1$$ to obtain xy as the denominator for each fraction.
speech: We must multiple each expression by the appropriate form of  1  to obtain xy as the denominator for each fraction.
pacedSpeech: We must multiple each expression by the appropriate form of   1
to obtain xy as the denominator for each fraction.

title: Multiplication by $$1$$
text: What should we multiply to $$\frac{3}{x+5}$$ so that its denominator becomes $$\left(x+5\right) \left(x-3\right)$$?
speech: What should we multiply to  fraction, 3 over, x plus 5,   so that its denominator becomes  parentheses x plus 5,  times, parentheses x minus 3,  ?
pacedSpeech: What should we multiply to   fraction, 3 over, x plus 5,
so that its denominator becomes    x plus 5,  times,  x minus 3,

title: Multiplication by $$1$$
text: What should we multiply to $$\frac{1}{x-3}$$ so that its denominator becomes $$\left(x+5\right) \left(x-3\right)$$?
speech: What should we multiply to  fraction, 1 over, x minus 3,   so that its denominator becomes  parentheses x plus 5,  times, parentheses x minus 3,  ?
pacedSpeech: What should we multiply to   fraction, 1 over, x minus 3,
so that its denominator becomes    x plus 5,  times,  x minus 3,

title: Adding Terms
text: Now that both terms have the same denominator, we can add their numerators. What is our final answer?
speech: Now that both terms have the same denominator, we can add their numerators. What is our final answer?
